AU: Hirose, T
AF: Hirose, T.
TI: A vegetative plant growth model: adaptive significance of phenotypic plasticity in matter
DE: Model; growth; plasticity; partitioning; specific leaf weight; dry matter; nitrogen; relative growth rate; nitrogen productivity
AB: A model of vegetative plant growth was constructed upon three assumptions derived from a sand-culture experiment with Polygonum cuspidatum Sieb. et Zucc.: (1) the partitioning of dry matter and nitrogen between organs is controlled by the nitrogen concentration of the whole plant; (2) specific leaf weight (SLW) is controlled by leaf nitrogen concentration; and (3) net assimilation rate is a function of nitrogen concentration per unit leaf area. Model simulations gave the relative growth rates under steady-state exponential growth for different nitrogen uptake rates per unit root weight. The significance of phenotypic plasticity in matter partitioning and SLW is discussed, comparing the growth of plants which modify their partitioning and SLW with those less plastic in these respects. Plants with plasticity in both matter partitioning and SLW always attained the higher growth rate under varying availabilities of nitrogen in the environment. Plasticity also contributed to the efficient use of nitrogen in plant growth.
C1: [Hirose, T.] Univ Tokyo, Dept Bot, Fac Sci, Tokyo 113, Japan
RP: Hirose, T (reprint author), Univ Utrecht, Dept Plant Ecol, Lange Nieuwstr 106, NL-3512 PN Utrecht, Netherlands.
FU: Ministry of Education, Science and Culture, Japan [60480004]
FX: I thank Marinus J. A. Werger and Hans Lambers for their comments. The Netherlands Organization for the Advancement of Pure Research (Z.W.O.) allowed me to prepare this paper during my stay at the Department of Plant Ecology, University of Utrecht. This study was partly supported by the Grant-in-Aid (no. 60480004) from the Ministry of Education, Science and Culture, Japan. This paper is dedicated to Professors Masami Monsi and Toshiro Saeki, great pioneers of plant production ecology.
